primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: Jesus, as the Lord of the Sabbath, enters the human condition of 'restlessness' and 'work' to achieve a final 'rest' (salvation) that humans cannot achieve through moralism or irreligion.

tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus is about to restore a man’s hand
I have finished the work that’s crushing you

object.identificatie: Sabbath Rest / Restoration of the Heart
tekstueel_bewijs: The Sabbath was made for man

zender.identificatie: God the Father / The Loving God
tekstueel_bewijs: It’s a gift from a loving God
God was saying: Obey me just because you trust me
Come unto me, all ye who labor
ontvanger.positie_hoorder: The hearer is positioned as the Receiver of a finished work, not the Subject of the rescue.

helper.identificatie: The Cross / The 'Cosmic Restlessness' of Jesus
tekstueel_bewijs: By cosmic restlessness... he got the restlessness you and I deserve
helper.rol_van_god: God is the Subject who provides the help through His own suffering.
helper.rol_van_geest: Implicit; the Spirit applies the 'finished work' to kill the 'lie of the serpent'.

tegenstander.identificatie: The Lie of the Serpent / The 'Work' of Self-Justification
tekstueel_bewijs: The lie of the Serpent has gone into every single human heart
The machinery of self-censorship... the inner murmur of self-reproach
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is an ontological condition (the Fall) that infects both the 'moral' and 'immoral' equally, making human effort futile.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The believer, having received rest, now obeys the law out of love rather than fear.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Believer
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The secondary program (ethics) is only possible after the primary program (soteriology) is completed by Jesus.

actantieel_schema_visualisatie.zender_naar_ontvanger: Loving Father → Sabbath Rest → The Heavy-Laden
actantieel_schema_visualisatie.helper_subject_tegenstander: The Cross → Jesus → The Lie of the Serpent

subject_check.mens_als_subject_count: Moderate (mostly in the context of 'failing' or 'working')
voorbeelden_god_subject: Jesus Christ says: I have completed the work
He got the restlessness you and I deserve
voorbeelden_mens_subject: We’ve been working ever since to get rid of that sense
The Pharisees went out and began to plot

voorbeelden: The religious leaders said you can and can’t do
I wanted her to love me
To understand the magnitude of it, it’s going to take us our entire time
I, only I, can give you rest

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon focuses on Christ's 'Power' to finish the work that the hearer's 'Duty' (Devoir) could never accomplish.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: The sermon moves from the tension between ~S1 (Pharisees) and ~S2 (Herodians) to show that both are actually S2 (Restlessness). It then moves to S1 (Rest) via Christ taking S2 on the cross.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Christ resolves the tension by becoming the 'Lord of the Sabbath'—taking the restlessness of the law to give the rest of grace.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High; S2 is described as an 'epic-scale' burden and 'cosmic' restlessness.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon is profoundly theocentric. It identifies the human problem not as a lack of effort, but as a deep-seated 'lie' that only Christ's finished work can heal.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus says David went in there and ate the bread.

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: I have finished the work that’s crushing you.
The lie of the Serpent has gone into every single human heart.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: David is used not as a moral example to follow, but as a theological pointer to the temporary nature of the ceremonial law.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already provides the theocentric reading: David points to the 'Lord of the Sabbath'.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief from the 'murmur of self-reproach'; psychological rest.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Justification by faith alone is the narrative engine.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The sermon perfectly integrates the biblical text with a systematic theology of grace.
spanning_punten: The tension between 'obeying' and 'resting' is resolved through the motive of love.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: He got the restlessness you and I deserve so that we could get the rest he has won for us.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The sermon focuses more on the objective work of Christ than the subjective work of the Spirit.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Critical; sin is a 'lie' that infects all human responses to God.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The narrative structure is soundly grace-oriented, with Christ as the sole Subject of the primary salvific action.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain current balance; it serves the grace-orientation.
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Perhaps more on the Spirit's role in the 'slow' process of killing the lie.

tegenstander_intensivering.huidige_status: The opponent (The Lie) is already presented as a cosmic, inescapable force.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This sermon is a masterclass in avoiding moralism by redefining the 'Sabbath' not as a human duty but as a divine person.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: A rhetorical analysis would focus on the 'three points' (Anger, Enemies, Claim); Greimas shows the underlying 'Subject-Object' shift from Man to Christ.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains the Pharisees' 39 rules; Greimas explains why those rules function as an 'Opponent' to the heart's rest.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas exposes that 'irreligion' and 'moralism' are actantially identical (both are the Subject trying to reach the Object through 'Work').

appendices.notities: The sermon uses the 'Chariots of Fire' illustration to effectively contrast two different actantial subjects (Abrahams vs. Liddell).
